item.title: In Talks, Trump Won’t Allow Iran to Have Any Enriched Uranium
item.description: Can the two sides get past Iran’s claim that it has a “right” to enrich uranium?
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers at a uranium conversion facility in Isfahan, Iran, in 2005. Analysts say Iran’s position on enrichment reflects the country’s intense pride in a nuclear program that has become a symbol of Iranian independence.

item.title: Netanyahu Suggests Other Officials to Blame for Oct. 7 Failings
item.description: In a document released on Thursday night, the Israeli leader sought to distance himself from responsibility for intelligence and security failings before the Hamas-led attack.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, and President Isaac Herzog, right, at a memorial last week for Ran Gvili, an off-duty police officer killed during the Oct. 7, 2023, attack.

item.title: Iran Is at Work on Missile and Nuclear Sites, Satellite Images Show
item.description: Repairs at key missile sites began soon after they were hit by Israeli and U.S. strikes last year, but work at Iran’s nuclear facilities has been slower.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Granados and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: How We Know Iran Crushed Protests with Lethal Force
item.description: The New York Times collected and analyzed hundreds of videos of a crackdown on anti-government protests that Iranians shared despite an internet blackout. Sanjana Varghese explains how the Visual Investigations team at The Times verified them.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese, Christina Thornell, James Surdam, Jon Hazell and Zach Caldwell

item.title: Iranian Nobel Peace Laureate Starts New Hunger Strike in Prison
item.description: The rights activist Narges Mohammadi is protesting her continued detention, her family said. She was arrested again in December after being given leave from prison for medical treatment.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Nooshin Jafari/Middle East Images, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi in Tehran last year while on temporary leave from prison. She was released for medical treatment in 2024 before being arrested again last year.

item.title: ‘It’s Collective Punishment’: Iran Exacts Heavy Price on Protest Supporters
item.description: The authorities are making mass arrests, seizing assets and hunting down doctors who treated protesters. Some Iranians keep showing defiance anyway.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Leily Nikounazar and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of an Iranian counterterrorism police unit at a pro-government rally in Tehran last month.

item.title: Outside the Art World’s Echo Chamber, at Art Basel Qatar
item.description: More than half the exhibited artists were from the Middle East, North Africa or South Asia, giving visitors an opportunity to discover fresh voices.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.category: Sheikha Al Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani
item.media:credit: Adriane de Souza for The New York Times
item.media:description: A work by El Anatsui at the October Gallery booth at Art Basel in Doha, Qatar.

item.title: ‘My Crazy Friend’: The Royals Who Stayed Close to Epstein
item.description: Emails, texts, photos and videos show how Jeffrey Epstein, even after becoming a convicted sex offender, burnished his ties to royal family members from several countries and their advisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Lise Aserud/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway at an event in Oslo in 2024.

item.title: U.S. and Iran to Hold Talks in Oman on Friday
item.description: The White House confirmed a meeting would take place after days of conflicting reports on the talks’ timing, location and format.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Burak Kara/Getty Images
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, was expected to meet with U.S. envoys in Oman on Friday.

item.title: Two Quit Human Rights Watch Over Shelved Report Criticizing Israel
item.description: Omar Shakir and Milena Ansari said they had quit over the stalled publication of a report that concludes it is a crime against humanity to deny Palestinians the ability to return to the territory that is now Israel.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Jerusalem in 2021.

item.title: Chevron Agrees to Explore Oil and Gas Work in Syria
item.description: Chevron has signed an initial agreement to start working in Syria, weeks after the Syrian government seized control of key oil and gas fields in the north of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ghaith Alsayed/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Tishrin oil field in northeastern Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Launches Deadly Strikes on Gaza, Saying Militants Attacked Its Soldiers
item.description: Gaza officials said the Israeli airstrikes killed at least 21 Palestinians. Israel said one of its soldiers was critically wounded in the attack by Palestinian gunmen.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Ramadan Abed/Reuters

item.title: Yair Golan’s Battle for a Two-State Solution and the Future of Israel
item.description: To many Israelis, he’s a war hero. To others, he’s a traitor guilty of “blood libel.” Can Yair Golan change politics in Israel?
item.dc:creator: Ruth Margalit
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Golan at an open discussion in December at Kibbutz Naan.

item.title: Gloves Come Off in Gulf as Trump’s Closest Arab Allies Clash
item.description: A feud between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates is reshaping conflicts and alliances across the Middle East and Africa.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: The site of a recent car-bomb attack in southern Yemen.

item.title: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, Son of Libyan Dictator, Is Killed
item.description: Mr. el-Qaddafi, 53, a politician and a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was killed after four men stormed his house, the lawyer said. No other details were released.
item.dc:creator: Islam Al-Atrash and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi gave an interview to The New York Times in Tripoli, Libya, in 2011.

item.title: Paris Court Deals Family Blow in Battle for Rent From the French Embassy in Iraq
item.description: The court said it was not the right authority to handle the lawsuit for unpaid rent, and the case should be heard in Iraq, where the family’s ancestors had fled persecution.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Provided by the Lawee and Khazzam families
item.media:description: The French Embassy in Baghdad is in a house built in the 1930s.

item.title: U.S. Fighter Jet Shoots Down Iranian Drone Amid Heightened Tensions
item.description: A U.S. fighter jet shot down the Iranian drone after it “unnecessarily maneuvered” toward the Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Fazry Ismail
item.media:description: F/A-18 fighter jets parked on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln in 2024.

item.title: Palestinians Return to Gaza for First Time in Nearly Two Years
item.description: Only 12 returnees were allowed to cross the newly reopened border with Egypt on the first day, far fewer than the expected number.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians embraced people who returned to Gaza late on Monday after the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza was reopened.

item.title: Iran’s President Backs ‘Fair’ Talks With U.S. as Confrontation Looms
item.description: President Masoud Pezeshkian said on Tuesday that he supported “equitable negotiations.” Talks are expected on Friday, as diplomats work to defuse the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran last month depicted strikes on an American aircraft carrier.

item.title: A Hamas Hostage’s Secret Ordeal
item.description: Guy Gilboa-Dalal says he was sexually abused by one of his captors in the tunnels of Gaza and threatened with death if he said anything.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guy Gilboa-Dalal near his parents’ home in Alfei Menashe, West Bank, in December. Mr. Gilboa-Dalal was abducted to Gaza from the Nova music festival on Oct. 7, 2023, and was released after more than two years in captivity.

item.title: U.S. and Iranian Officials to Meet as Trump’s Threats Loom
item.description: President Trump’s Middle East envoy and his son-in-law were expected to meet Iran’s foreign minister in Istanbul on Friday amid tensions between the countries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran showing Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, reads “We recognize the American president as a criminal.”

item.title: Erfan Soltani, Who Reportedly Faced Death Sentence in Iran, Is Freed
item.description: Mr. Soltani, 26, was arrested last month as Iran brutally repressed anti-government demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Rafah Crossing in Gaza Reopens, Another Step for Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel and Egypt had disagreed for months about how to resume operations at the Rafah border crossing, which has been largely closed since May 2024.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A medical convoy carrying patients in Khan Younis, Gaza, heading for the Rafah crossing on Monday. The opening of the crossing is expected to expedite the exit of thousands of sick and wounded people waiting for treatment abroad.

item.title: Oscar-Nominated Screenwriter Arrested in Iran for Criticizing Regime
item.description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, co-writer of “It Was Just an Accident,” was one of several people detained after signing a letter objecting to the crackdown on protests.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, a political activist and screenwriter, during an interview in Tehran in 2021.

item.title: U.A.E. Firm Quietly Took Stake in the Trump Family’s Crypto Company
item.description: The $500 million agreement raises new concerns about the propriety of the president negotiating foreign policy with his own business partners.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zach Witkoff, left, and Eric Trump, speaking in Dubai in May. Eric Trump signed an agreement with an Emirati-backed investment firm days before his father’s inauguration in January 2025.

item.title: What to Know About the Rafah Border Crossing in Gaza
item.description: The only crossing that connects Gaza with Egypt has reopened. The move will allow residents to leave for medical care or return to homes and families in the territory.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah border crossing between the Gaza Strip and Egypt in 2023.

item.title: Explosions in Iran Spread Jitters and Rumors Amid Anticipation of Attacks
item.description: Deadly blasts, including one that may have been caused by a gas leak, raised anxiety in the country. “Society is waiting for war,” one Iranian said.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar and Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A video image posted on social media on Saturday showed the aftermath of an explosion at a building in Bandar Abbas, a port in southern Iran.

item.title: Israel Launches Attack in Gaza
item.description: A local health official said at least 26 people had been killed in the attacks, which the Israeli military said had targeted Hamas commanders.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourning their loved ones after Israeli airstrikes in Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: These Gazans May Finally Get a Lifeline to the World
item.description: Thousands of Palestinians are waiting to be evacuated for medical treatment as the border between Gaza and Egypt looks set to reopen in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Saher Alghorra, Bilal Shbair and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Mohammed al-Ser suffered a severe head injury in June that left him partly paralyzed. He is depicted before he underwent cranial surgery this week, but doctors say he needs care outside Gaza to fully recover.
